item.name: L2V Ratio (lCores:vCores)
item.key: custom.calculated.l2vratio
item.description: L2V (Physical:Virtual) Ratio -> Logical Cores to virtual Cores Ratio (Hyperthreaded Cores included)

item.name: P2V Ratio (pCores:vCores)
item.key: custom.calculated.p2vratio
item.params: last("system.run[powershell.exe \"(gcim -Namespace root\virtualization\v2 -ClassName MSVM_Processor | where {$_.OperationalStatus -match 40002}).count\"]")/last("system.run[powershell.exe \"(gcim -ClassName CIM_Processor | measure -Property NumberOfCores -Sum).Sum\"]")
item.description: P2V (Physical:Virtual) Ratio -> Physical Cores to virtual Cores Ratio (Hyperthreaded Cores excluded)

item.name: Hyper-V Number of VMs (off)
item.key: custom.calculated.vms_off
item.params: (last("perf_counter[\Hyper-V Virtual Machine Health Summary\Health Critical]")+last("perf_counter[\Hyper-V Virtual Machine Health Summary\Health Ok]"))-last("system.run[powershell.exe "((get-vm).State -eq 'Running').count"]")

item.name: Ping to the iLO-Interface (ICMP ping)
item.key: icmpping[{HOST.HOST}a]

item.name: CSV IO Read Avg. Queue Length (Total)
item.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System(_Total)\IO Read Avg. Queue Length]
item.description: These two counters tell how many outstanding reads and writes we have on average per second. If we assume that all IOs are dispatched using Direct IO then value of this counter will be approximately equal to PhysicalDisk\Avg.Disk Write Queue Length and PhysicalDisk\Avg.Disk Read Queue Length accordingly. If IO is sent using Block Level Redirected IO then this counter will be reflecting SMB latency, which you can monitor using SMB Client Shares\Avg. Write Queue Length and SMB Client Shares\Avg. Read Queue Length.

item.name: CSV IO Read Latency (Total)
item.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System(_Total)\IO Read Latency]

item.name: CSV IO Write Avg. Queue Length (Total)
item.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System(_Total)\IO Write Avg. Queue Length]
item.description: These two counters tell how many outstanding reads and writes we have on average per second. If we assume that all IOs are dispatched using Direct IO then value of this counter will be approximately equal to PhysicalDisk\Avg.Disk Write Queue Length and PhysicalDisk\Avg.Disk Read Queue Length accordingly. If IO is sent using Block Level Redirected IO then this counter will be reflecting SMB latency, which you can monitor using SMB Client Shares\Avg. Write Queue Length and SMB Client Shares\Avg. Read Queue Length.

item.name: CSV IO Write Latency (Total)
item.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System(_Total)\IO Write Latency]

item.name: CSV Redirected Read Bytes/s (Total)
item.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System(_Total)\Redirected Read Bytes/sec]

item.name: CSV Redirected Write Bytes/s (Total)
item.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System(_Total)\Redirected Write Bytes/sec]

item.name: Cluster Service Missing Heartbeats Limit
item.key: perf_counter[\Cluster Netft Heartbeats(clussvc.exe)\Missing heartbeats limit]

item.name: Cluster Service Missing Heartbeats
item.key: perf_counter[\Cluster Netft Heartbeats(clussvc.exe)\Missing heartbeats]

item.name: Hyper-V RHS Processes
item.key: perf_counter[\Cluster Resource Control Manager\RHS Processes]

item.name: Hyper-V RHS restarts
item.key: perf_counter[\Cluster Resource Control Manager\RHS Restarts]

item.name: Hyper-V Logical CPU Guest Runtime %
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(_Total)\% Guest Run Time]
item.description: The percentage of time spent by the processor in guest code.

item.name: Hyper-V Logical CPU Hypervisor Runtime %
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(_Total)\% Hypervisor Run Time]
item.description: The percentage of time spent by the processor in hypervisor code.

item.name: Hyper-V Logical CPU Idle Runtime %
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(_Total)\% Idle Time]
item.description: The percentage of time spent by the processor in an idle state.

item.name: Hyper-V Logical CPU Total Runtime %
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(_Total)\% Total Run Time]
item.description: The percentage of time spent by the processor in guest and hypervisor code.

item.name: Hyper-V Logical CPU Context Switches per Second
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(_Total)\Context Switches/sec]

item.name: Hyper-V Root Virtual CPU Guest Runtime %
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Virtual Processor(_Total)\% Guest Run Time]
item.description: The percentage of time spent by the virtual processor in guest code.

item.name: Hyper-V Root Virtual CPU Hypervisor Runtime %
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Virtual Processor(_Total)\% Hypervisor Run Time]
item.description: The percentage of time spent by the virtual processor in hypervisor code.

item.name: Hyper-V Root Virtual CPU Remote Runtime %
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Virtual Processor(_Total)\% Remote Run Time]
item.description: The percentage of time spent by the virtual processor running on a remote node.

item.name: Hyper-V Root Virtual CPU Total Runtime %
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Virtual Processor(_Total)\% Total Run Time]
item.description: The percentage of time spent by the virtual processor in guest and hypervisor code.

item.name: Hyper-V Root Virtual CPU Wait Time per Dispatch (avg)
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Root Virtual Processor(_Total)\CPU Wait Time per Dispatch]

item.name: Hyper-V Virtual CPU Guest Runtime %
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Virtual Processor(_Total)\% Guest Run Time]
item.description: The percentage of time spent by the virtual processor in guest code.

item.name: Hyper-V Virtual CPU Hypervisor Runtime %
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Virtual Processor(_Total)\% Hypervisor Run Time]
item.description: The percentage of time spent by the virtual processor in hypervisor code.

item.name: Hyper-V Virtual CPU Remote Runtime %
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Virtual Processor(_Total)\% Remote Run Time]
item.description: The percentage of time spent by the virtual processor running on a remote node.

item.name: Hyper-V Virtual CPU Total Runtime %
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Virtual Processor(_Total)\% Total Run Time]
item.description: The percentage of time spent by the virtual processor in guest and hypervisor code.

item.name: Hyper-V Virtual CPU Wait Time per Dispatch (avg)
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Virtual Processor(_Total)\CPU Wait Time per Dispatch]

item.name: Hyper-V Number of lCores
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor\Logical Processors]
item.description: These are the number of cores / HT that the hypervisor is managing. If you have a dual proc quad core without HT you will see this number set to 8. If you also had HT it would be set to 16. Today this value is fixed after boot and won’t change. In the future we may support hot add and remove of processors in which case this will be dynamic.

item.name: Hyper-V Monitored Notifications
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor\Monitored Notifications]
item.description: Monitored notifications are part of an interrupt coalescing technique Hyper-V uses to reduce virtualization overhead. For example when a guest has data to transmit over the network it could send an interrupt for each packet to the root VP that will actually do the I/O or it can send one interrupt to let the root know data is starting to flow. This counter is an indication of the number of “flows” of interrupts being set to the root and guests.

item.name: Hyper-V Number of Partitions (Root + VMs)
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor\Partitions]
item.description: Each virtual machine on the system is run in a container called a partition. If you have no VM’s running this value will be set to 1 because the “host OS” called the “root” in Hyper-V is also running in a partition. So if you have 2 guest VM’s running this value will be 3. +1 for each guest and +1 for the root.

item.name: Hyper-V Total Pages
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor\Total Pages]
item.description: The Hypervisor needs memory in order to keep track of Virtual Processors, Guest Virtual address to System Physical Address translation entries in the virtual TLB, etc. So the total pages keep track of the total amount of memory the Hypervisor is using for management or partitions. A page is 4KBytes. This is not the total amount used to support a guest. You would also need to get this by looking at the size of the worker process (vmwp.exe) and account for memory in vid.

item.name: Hyper-V VMs Critical
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Virtual Machine Health Summary\Health Critical]
item.description: The number of critical VMs on a host.

item.name: Hyper-V VMs OK
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Virtual Machine Health Summary\Health Ok]
item.description: The number of OK VM's on a host.

item.name: Hyper-V Virtual Switch Bytes/s Received
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Virtual Switch(*)\Bytes Received/sec]
item.description: This counter indicates the total bytes received per second on all ports of your Virtual Switch.

item.name: Hyper-V Virtual Switch Bytes/s Sent
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Virtual Switch(*)\Bytes Sent/sec]
item.description:
This counter indicates the total bytes sent per second on all ports of your Virtual Switch.
There are other interesting counters inside the Hyper-V Virtual Switch Object but are for other reasons rather than capacity and consumption.
Note that this counter may show the double consumption compared with the \Network Interface\Bytes Total/sec because it counts the Input and Output traffic of each port. If a Virtual Machine that is connected to an External Switch is sending 1000 bytes/sec this will means that the Virtual Switch is seeing 1000 bytes/sec on the port where the VM is connected and also 1000 bytes on the port of the switch that is connected to the external world.

item.name: Hyper-V Virtual Switch "Ethernet Trunk" Bytes/s Received
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Virtual Switch(Ethernet Trunk)\Bytes Received/sec]

item.name: Hyper-V Virtual Switch "Ethernet Trunk" Bytes/s Sent
item.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Virtual Switch(Ethernet Trunk)\Bytes Sent/sec]

item.name: Hyper-V Pages per Second
item.key: perf_counter[\Memory\Pages/sec]
item.description: Pages/sec is the rate at which pages are read from or written to disk to resolve hard page faults. This counter is a primary indicator of the kinds of faults that cause system-wide delays. It is the sum of Memory\\Pages Input/sec and Memory\\Pages Output/sec. It is counted in numbers of pages, so it can be compared to other counts of pages, such as Memory\\Page Faults/sec, without conversion. It includes pages retrieved to satisfy faults in the file system cache (usually requested by applications) non-cached mapped memory files.

item.name: Service Cluster Service (clussvc) Memory usage
item.key: perf_counter[\Process(clussvc)\Working Set - Private]
item.description: Memory Usage of the cluster service (clussvc) in Bytes (Working Set - Private")

item.name: Service APIC (ApicHypervAgent)
item.key: service.info[ApicHypervAgent]
item.description: This service is for the ACI Integration. This service "mapps" the VLANs to the Hyper-V Nodes through the Opflex-Tunnel. (Only integrated Nodes has this service.)

item.name: Service ClusterService (clussvc)
item.key: service.info[clussvc]

item.name: Service SCVMMAgent state
item.key: service.info[SCVMMAgent]

item.name: Service Virtual Machine Management Service (VMMS) state
item.key: service.info[vmms]

item.name: Service Cluster Service (clussvc) CPU usage
item.key: system.run["powershell.exe [int](((Get-WmiObject Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfProc_Process -Filter \"Name='clussvc'\").PercentProcessorTime/((Get-WmiObject Win32_Processor).NumberOfLogicalProcessors ^| Measure-Object -Sum).sum))"]
item.description:
The percentage of time the cluster service use.
The following Perfmon-counter must divide by number of Cores: perf_counter[\Process(clussvc)\% Processor Time]

item.name: Memory used by Winmgmt-Process (WMI)
item.key: system.run[powershell.exe "(((Get-Process -Id ((Get-WmiObject win32_service | where { $_.name -eq 'winmgmt'}).processID)).PM))"]
item.description: Memory Usage of the WMI service (Winmgmt) in Bytes (Working Set - Private)

item.name: Hyper-V Number of pCores
item.key: system.run[powershell.exe "(gcim -ClassName CIM_Processor | measure -Property NumberOfCores -Sum).Sum"]
item.description: The Number of physical Cores (Hyperthreaded Cores excluded).

item.name: Hyper-V Number of VMs (running)
item.key: system.run[powershell.exe "(gcim -Namespace 'root\virtualization\v2' -Class Msvm_ComputerSystem | where {$_.Caption -eq 'Virtual Machine' -and $_.ProcessID -ne $null}).count"]
item.description: Number of VMs (only VMs in "Running" state)

item.name: Hyper-V Number of vCores (in use)
item.key: system.run[powershell.exe "(gcim -Namespace root\virtualization\v2 -ClassName MSVM_Processor | where {$_.OperationalStatus -match 40002}).count"]
item.description: Number of Virtual Cores including only VMs in running state. (Cores in use)

item.name: Hyper-V Number of vCores
item.key: system.run[powershell.exe "(gcim -Namespace root\virtualization\v2 -ClassName MSVM_Processor | where {$_.Role -match 'Virtual'}).count"]
item.description: Number of Virtual Cores including in VMs in off state.

item.name: Number of Handles (total)
item.key: system.run[powershell.exe "(Get-CimInstance Win32_PerfRawData_PerfProc_Process | ? {$_.Name -eq '_Total'}).HandleCount"]
item.description: Number of total Handles on the Node.

item.name: Number of Threads (total)
item.key: system.run[powershell.exe "(Get-CimInstance Win32_PerfRawData_PerfProc_Process | ? {$_.Name -eq '_Total'}).ThreadCount"]
item.description: Number of total Threads on the Node.

item.name: Number of CSV (Coordinator)
item.key: system.run[powershell.exe "(Get-ClusterSharedVolume | ? {$_.OwnerNode -eq (hostname)}).count"]
item.description: Number of CSV Coordinator/Owner on this Node.

item.name: Hyper-V Network Interface Status NIC01
item.key: system.run[powershell.exe "(Get-NetAdapter -Name NIC01).Status"]

item.name: Hyper-V Network Interface Status NIC02
item.key: system.run[powershell.exe "(Get-NetAdapter -Name NIC02).Status"]

item.name: CPU Clock Speed
item.key: system.run[powershell.exe "Get-CimInstance -ClassName CIM_Processor -Property MaxClockSpeed | select -ExpandProperty MaxClockSpeed -First 1"]

item_prototype.name: CSV IO Read Avg. Queue Length {#CSVNAME}
item_prototype.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System({#CSVNAME})\IO Read Avg. Queue Length]

item_prototype.name: CSV IO Read Bytes/s {#CSVNAME}
item_prototype.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System({#CSVNAME})\IO Read Bytes/sec]

item_prototype.name: CSV IO Read latency {#CSVNAME}
item_prototype.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System({#CSVNAME})\IO Read Latency]
item_prototype.description: Tells you how many seconds read/write operations take on average. If you see a value 0.003 that means IO takes 3 milliseconds. When all IO are sent using Direct IO then this value should be very close to PhysicalDisk\Avg.Disk sec/Read and PhysicalDisk\Avg.Disk sec/Write accordingly. If IO are sent using Block Level Redirected IO then counters value should be close to Smb Client Share\Avg.sec/Write and Smb Client Share\Avg.sec/Read.

item_prototype.name: CSV IO Write Avg. Queue Length {#CSVNAME}
item_prototype.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System({#CSVNAME})\IO Write Avg. Queue Length]

item_prototype.name: CSV IO Write Bytes/s {#CSVNAME}
item_prototype.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System({#CSVNAME})\IO Write Bytes/sec]

item_prototype.name: CSV IO Write latency {#CSVNAME}
item_prototype.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System({#CSVNAME})\IO Write Latency]
item_prototype.description: Tells you how many seconds read/write operations take on average. If you see a value 0.003 that means IO takes 3 milliseconds. When all IO are sent using Direct IO then this value should be very close to PhysicalDisk\Avg.Disk sec/Read and PhysicalDisk\Avg.Disk sec/Write accordingly. If IO are sent using Block Level Redirected IO then counters value should be close to Smb Client Share\Avg.sec/Write and Smb Client Share\Avg.sec/Read.

item_prototype.name: CSV Redirected Read Bytes/s {#CSVNAME}
item_prototype.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System({#CSVNAME})\Redirected Read Bytes/sec]

item_prototype.name: CSV Redirected Write Bytes/s {#CSVNAME}
item_prototype.key: perf_counter[\Cluster CSV File System({#CSVNAME})\Redirected Write Bytes/sec]

item_prototype.name: CSV State {#CSVNAME}
item_prototype.description: 0 – Init state. In that state all files are invalidated and all IOs except volume IOs are failing. 1 – Paused state. In this state volume will pause any new IO and down-level state is cleaned. 2 – Draining state. In this state volume will pause any new IO, but down-level files are still opened and some down-level IOs might be still in process. 3 – Set Down Level state. In this state volume will pause any new IO. The down-level state is already reapplied. 4 – Active state. In this state all IO are proceeding as normal. Down-level in the state descriptions above refer to the state that CSVFS has on the NTFS. Example of that state would be files opened by CSVFS on NTFS, byte range locks, file delete disposition, oplock states etc.

item_prototype.name: Coordinator of CSV Volume {#CSVNAME} is this node?

trigger_prototype.name: OS: Windows: More than 80% on CSV Volume {#CSVNAME}
OS: Windows: More than 90% on CSV Volume {#CSVNAME}

item_prototype.name: Number of HBA Paths on Disk {#DISKNUMBER} ({#UNIQUEID})
item_prototype.description: This Item shows the Number of HBA Paths is available per Disk.

item_prototype.name: HealthStatus of LUN on Disk {#DISKNUMBER} ({#UNIQUEID})
item_prototype.description: This Item shows the HealthStatus of a LUN.

item_prototype.name: Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor Core {#CPU.NUMBER} % Total Run Time
item_prototype.key: perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(Hv LP {#CPU.NUMBER})\% Total Run Time]

trigger.expression: {TPL-FA-Compute-Hyper-V:perf_counter[\Hyper-V Hypervisor Logical Processor(_Total)\% Total Run Time].avg(#5)}>95
trigger.name: OS: Hyper-V Host CPU > 95%
OS: Hyper-V host has 0 VMs in OK state
trigger.description: Number of VMs in an OK state.

trigger.name: OS: Hyper-V host has critical VMs
trigger.description: The number of VMs running in a critical state.

trigger.name: OS: Hyper-V Network Interface Status NIC01
OS: Hyper-V Network Interface Status NIC02
OS: Hyper-V Service used Memory (winmgmt)
trigger.description: The Service "winmgmt" used to much Memory. (>2GB)

trigger.name: OS: Hyper-V Virtual to logical CPU Ratio > 5:1
OS: Hyper-V Virtual to physical CPU Ratio > 5:1
OS: Ping to the iLO-Interface (ICMP ping) - down
OS: Windows: Service: ApicHypervAgent not running
trigger.description: The APIC Agent is not running. If this occurs longer than 5min all VLAN through the Opflex-Tunnel are gone.
